I'm trying to unpack the definition of Stoch (the Kleisli category of the Giry monad) as a Markov category. My goal is to be able to take any string diagram and be able to express it explicitly in terms of measure-theoretic integrals, in order to prove properties of Stoch. I don't know much measure theory and am trying to learn what I need as I go along.

So far the best resource I've found for unpacking Stoch is Panangaden's 'The Category of Markov Kernels' (1999), which is really helpful but stops short of completely answering my question. The tricky part is in the details of how to reason about the interaction between the monoidal product and composition, as I explain below.

Here is what I know so far:

Objects are measurable spaces, which I'll write as (X,ΣX)(X,\Sigma_X)(X,ΣX​). I'll write σX,τX\sigma_X, \tau_XσX​,τX​ etc. for elements of ΣX\Sigma_XΣX​.

Then a morphism f ⁣:X→Yf\colon X\to Yf:X→Y is a map f ⁣:ΣY×X→[0,1]f\colon \Sigma_Y\times X\to [0,1]f:ΣY​×X→[0,1], where we write f(σY∣x)f(\sigma_Y\mid x)f(σY​∣x) for f(σY,x)f(\sigma_Y,x)f(σY​,x). This must have the properties that

  • f(−∣x) ⁣:ΣY→[0,1]f({-}\mid x)\colon \Sigma_Y\to [0,1]f(−∣x):ΣY​→[0,1] is a probability measure for every x∈Xx\in Xx∈X

  • f(B∣−) ⁣:X→[0,1]f(B\mid{-})\colon X\to [0,1]f(B∣−):X→[0,1] is a measurable function for every B∈ΣYB\in\Sigma_YB∈ΣY​.

Composition X→fY→gZX\xrightarrow{f}Y\xrightarrow{g}ZXf​Yg​Z is given by

(f;g)(σZ∣x)=∫y∈Yg(σZ∣y) d f(y∣x). (f;g)(\sigma_Z\mid x) = \int_{y\in Y} g(\sigma_Z\mid y) \,d\, f(y\mid x).(f;g)(σZ​∣x)=∫y∈Y​g(σZ​∣y)df(y∣x).

There is some work needed to see that this function has the needed properties and that composition is associative. Panangaden gives an explicit proof of associativity. Identities are Dirac deltas.

The monoidal product is given on objects by (X×Y,ΣX⊗ΣY)(X\times Y, \Sigma_X\otimes \Sigma_Y)(X×Y,ΣX​⊗ΣY​), where ΣX⊗ΣY\Sigma_X\otimes \Sigma_YΣX​⊗ΣY​ is the product σ\sigmaσ-algebra. For morphisms f ⁣:A→Xf\colon A\to Xf:A→X and g ⁣:B→Yg\colon B\to Yg:B→Y we define

(f⊗g)(σX×σY∣a,b)=f(σX∣a)g(σY∣b). (f\otimes g)(\sigma_{X}\times \sigma_{Y}\mid a,b) = f(\sigma_{X}\mid a)g(\sigma_{Y}\mid b).(f⊗g)(σX​×σY​∣a,b)=f(σX​∣a)g(σY​∣b).

This defines the measure only on elements of ΣX⊗ΣY\Sigma_X\otimes \Sigma_YΣX​⊗ΣY​ that are of the form σX×σY\sigma_{X}\times \sigma_{Y}σX​×σY​, but this uniquely extends to a measure on ΣX⊗ΣY\Sigma_X\otimes \Sigma_YΣX​⊗ΣY​ by Carathéodory's extension theorem.

So far so good. The tricky part is in figuring out how composition and this monoidal product relate to each other.

For example, suppose I have morphisms f ⁣:A→Xf\colon A\to Xf:A→X, g ⁣:B→Yg\colon B\to Yg:B→Y and h ⁣:X⊗Y→Zh\colon X\otimes Y\to Zh:X⊗Y→Z, and I want to calculate (f⊗g)⨾h(f\otimes g) \mathbin{⨾} h(f⊗g)⨾h. The morphism f⊗gf\otimes gf⊗g is as defined above, but in order to compose it with hhh I need to be able to integrate against it - I can't see a way to write (f⊗g)⨾h(f\otimes g) \mathbin{⨾} h(f⊗g)⨾h down as a single equation because of the step where we extend the partially defined measure to a full one.

Ultimately I want to be able to prove that certain morphisms are equal under certain conditions, and this sort of thing is causing a roadblock to that. So I guess my questions are

1) can the morphism (f⊗g)⨾h(f\otimes g) \mathbin{⨾} h(f⊗g)⨾h be written down explicitly in a nice way?

2) is there somewhere where this explicit unpacking of Stoch is done and written down already?

If these questions get answers I might have more questions as well, but let's see how this goes.
It can't hurt to email Prakash: he's a friendly guy and he'd be happy to know someone is interested in this.

You could write it down as an integral. For all measurable

p:Z→[0,∞]p: Z \to [0, \infty]p:Z→[0,∞]

we have

∫((f⊗g);h)(a,b,dz)p(z)=∫f(a,dx)∫g(b,dy)∫h(x,y,dz) p(z).\int ((f \otimes g); h)(a, b, \text{d}z) p(z) = \int f(a, \text{d}x) \int g(b, \text{d}y) \int h(x, y, \text{d}z) \, p(z).∫((f⊗g);h)(a,b,dz)p(z)=∫f(a,dx)∫g(b,dy)∫h(x,y,dz)p(z).

Hence,

((f⊗g);h)(a,b,dz)=f(a,dx)g(b,dy)h(x,y,dz)((f \otimes g); h)(a, b, \text{d}z) = f(a, \text{d}x) g(b, \text{d}y) h(x, y, \text{d}z)((f⊗g);h)(a,b,dz)=f(a,dx)g(b,dy)h(x,y,dz)

using the notation in https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-0-387-87859-1

Sorry if this is a bit brief, but I think that the explicit formula should simply be

((f⊗g);h)(S∣a,b)=∫x∈X∫y∈Yh(S∣x,y) df(x∣a) dg(y∣b).((f \otimes g) ; h)(S|a,b) = \int_{x \in X} \int_{y \in Y} h(S|x,y) \, df(x|a) \, dg(y|b).((f⊗g);h)(S∣a,b)=∫x∈X​∫y∈Y​h(S∣x,y)df(x∣a)dg(y∣b).

This is basically the same equation as calculating the expectation value of a measurable function with respect to a product measure. BTW I personally prefer writing this as

(f⊗g);h)(S∣a,b)=∫x∈X∫y∈Yh(S∣x,y) f(dx∣a) g(dy∣b),(f \otimes g) ; h)(S|a,b) = \int_{x \in X} \int_{y \in Y} h(S|x,y) \, f(dx|a) \, g(dy|b),(f⊗g);h)(S∣a,b)=∫x∈X​∫y∈Y​h(S∣x,y)f(dx∣a)g(dy∣b),

with the ddd's at the integration variables, which seems more intuitive.

Tobias Fritz said:

Sorry if this is a bit brief, but I think that the explicit formula should simply be

((f⊗g);h)(S∣a,b)=∫x∈X∫y∈Yh(S∣x,y) df(x∣a) dg(y∣b).((f \otimes g) ; h)(S|a,b) = \int_{x \in X} \int_{y \in Y} h(S|x,y) \, df(x|a) \, dg(y|b).((f⊗g);h)(S∣a,b)=∫x∈X​∫y∈Y​h(S∣x,y)df(x∣a)dg(y∣b).

This is basically the same equation as calculating the expectation value of a measurable function with respect to a product measure.

Thank you, I'm sure this is right. (And brevity is good.) I was confused because I was actually trying to evaluate q;(f⊗g);hq;(f\otimes g);hq;(f⊗g);h for some q ⁣:1→X×Yq\colon 1\to X\times Yq:1→X×Y, and I was stuck at trying to integrate h(S∣x,y)h(S\mid x,y)h(S∣x,y) against q;(f⊗g)q;(f\otimes g)q;(f⊗g). The latter is a measure defined on a product space but it isn't a product measure, so I couldn't do this.

But your comment made me realise I can just evaluate it as q;((f⊗g);h)q;((f\otimes g);h)q;((f⊗g);h) instead and then there's no problem. Maybe this will always work - I can always just evaluate things from back to front and then I'll always either be integrating against a product measure or against a measure that's fully defined instead of partially defined and then extended. I'll try it on my real problem and see if it works.

BTW I personally prefer writing this as

(f⊗g);h)(S∣a,b)=∫x∈X∫y∈Yh(S∣x,y) f(dx∣a) g(dy∣b),(f \otimes g) ; h)(S|a,b) = \int_{x \in X} \int_{y \in Y} h(S|x,y) \, f(dx|a) \, g(dy|b),(f⊗g);h)(S∣a,b)=∫x∈X​∫y∈Y​h(S∣x,y)f(dx∣a)g(dy∣b),

with the ddd's at the integration variables, which seems more intuitive.

I write it the way I do because I think of ∫x∈Xf(x) d p(x)\int_{x\in X}f(x)\,d\,p(x)∫x∈X​f(x)dp(x) as a souped-up ⟨p,f⟩\langle p, f\rangle⟨p,f⟩ (applying a 'dual vector' to a 'vector'), where the xxx is a dummy variable and the ddd is really just the comma. But I can see the point of the other notation and will give it a try - it might be less confusing in the end.

Richard Samuelson said:

You could write it down as an integral. For all measurable

p:Z→[0,∞]p: Z \to [0, \infty]p:Z→[0,∞]

we have

∫((f⊗g);h)(a,b,dz)p(z)=∫h(x,y,dz)∫f(a,dx)∫g(b,dy) p(z).\int ((f \otimes g); h)(a, b, \text{d}z) p(z) = \int h(x, y, \text{d}z) \int f(a, \text{d}x) \int g(b, \text{d}y) \, p(z).∫((f⊗g);h)(a,b,dz)p(z)=∫h(x,y,dz)∫f(a,dx)∫g(b,dy)p(z).

Hence,

((f⊗g);h)(a,b,dz)=h(x,y,dz)f(a,dx)g(b,dy)((f \otimes g); h)(a, b, \text{d}z) = h(x, y, \text{d}z) f(a, \text{d}x) g(b, \text{d}y)((f⊗g);h)(a,b,dz)=h(x,y,dz)f(a,dx)g(b,dy)

using the notation in https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-0-387-87859-1

This makes me start to like the dxdxdx notation actually - I like being able to write it implicitly like this. But I think we can only get rid of one of the integral signs, because we still have to integrate over xxx and yyy. So I'd write this as

((f⊗g);h)(dz∣a,b)=∫y∈Y∫x∈Xh(dz∣x,y)f(dx∣a)g(dy∣b),((f \otimes g); h)(dz\mid a, b) = \int_{y\in Y}\int_{x\in X}h(dz\mid x, y) f(dx\mid a) g(dy\mid b),((f⊗g);h)(dz∣a,b)=∫y∈Y​∫x∈X​h(dz∣x,y)f(dx∣a)g(dy∣b),

which is basically what Tobias Fritz wrote only with dzdzdz in place of S∈ΣZS\in\Sigma_ZS∈ΣZ​.

I have one more question, which is as much a notation question as anything else. Suppose I have f ⁣:1→X⊗Yf\colon 1\to X\otimes Yf:1→X⊗Y and g ⁣:X⊗Y→Zg\colon X\otimes Y\to Zg:X⊗Y→Z. What's the right way to write down their composite?

It feels like I should be able to write it as

(f;g)(dz∣∙)=∫x,y∈X⊗Yg(dz∣x,y)f(dx,dy∣∙),(f;g)(dz\mid \bullet) = \int_{x,y\in X\otimes Y} g(dz\mid x, y) f(dx, dy\mid\bullet),(f;g)(dz∣∙)=∫x,y∈X⊗Y​g(dz∣x,y)f(dx,dy∣∙),

but I'm a bit uneasy about writing dxdxdx and dydydy, because the space being integrated over is X⊗YX\otimes YX⊗Y, not XXX and YYY separately. Is there a formal argument that allows it to be written this way, or should it really be something like

(f;g)(dz∣∙)=∫x,y∈X⊗Yg(dz∣x,y)f(d(x,y)∣∙)(f;g)(dz\mid \bullet) = \int_{x,y\in X\otimes Y} g(dz\mid x, y) f(d(x,y)\mid\bullet)(f;g)(dz∣∙)=∫x,y∈X⊗Y​g(dz∣x,y)f(d(x,y)∣∙)

instead?

Without a formal syntax in place, I'd say that both of those notations make sense since they express what you mean clearly enough. You could also write it as a double integral (by Fubini's theorem), and/or write dx×dydx \times dydx×dy in the argument of fff in order to express the idea that one sums up the measures of tiny rectangles.

I guess the semantics of these things is what I'm trying to grasp towards. Or at least I want to be sure I know what I mean when I write these things down.

Can I really use Fubini's theorem here? I thought I could only use that in the case where I'm integrating over a product measure. If I write

∫x∈X∫y∈Yg(S∣x,y)f(dx,dy∣∙)\int_{x\in X} \int_{y\in Y} g(S\mid x,y) f(dx, dy \mid \bullet)∫x∈X​∫y∈Y​g(S∣x,y)f(dx,dy∣∙)

then it looks to me like I need to evaluate something like

∫y∈Yg(S∣x,y)f(T,dy∣∙)\int_{y\in Y} g(S\mid x,y) f(T, dy \mid \bullet)∫y∈Y​g(S∣x,y)f(T,dy∣∙)

and then integrate that over XXX.

If that's right then what's the name of this kind of partial integral? I'm not getting much luck trying to google things like "integrating over one variable of a joint measure".

The same thing comes up in this situation: suppose I have q ⁣:A⊗Xq\colon A\otimes Xq:A⊗X and f ⁣:X→Yf\colon X\to Yf:X→Y, and I want to calculate q;(idA;f)q;(id_A;f)q;(idA​;f). I end up with

(q;(idA;f))(da,dy∣∙)=∫a′,x∈A⊗Xf(dy∣x)idA(da∣a′)  q(da,dx′∣∙).(q;(id_A;f))(da,dy\mid \bullet) = \int_{a', x\in A\otimes X} f(dy\mid x) id_A(da\mid a') \,\, q(da,dx'\mid \bullet).(q;(idA​;f))(da,dy∣∙)=∫a′,x∈A⊗X​f(dy∣x)idA​(da∣a′)q(da,dx′∣∙).

It seems like I should be able to integrate out a′a'a′ to get

(q;(idA;f))(da,dy∣∙)=∫x∈Xf(dy∣x)  q(da,dx∣∙).(q;(id_A;f))(da,dy\mid \bullet) = \int_{x\in X} f(dy\mid x) \,\, q(da,dx\mid \bullet).(q;(idA​;f))(da,dy∣∙)=∫x∈X​f(dy∣x)q(da,dx∣∙).

but then I'm back to integrating only over XXX even though qqq is a measure over A⊗XA\otimes XA⊗X, and I don't know what it means formally.
Urgh, sorry, I'm a bit out of it today -- please ignore my reference to Fubini, you're right that it's not that.

My original post was incorrect (I just edited it). I believe that the expression can be written

((f⊗g);h)(a,b,dz)=f(a,dx)g(b,dy)h(x,y,dz),((f \otimes g); h)(a, b, \text{d}z) = f(a, \text{d}x) g(b, \text{d}y) h(x, y, \text{d}z),((f⊗g);h)(a,b,dz)=f(a,dx)g(b,dy)h(x,y,dz),
